Thank god it's pretty good because otherwise I'd be forced to drive to the Inner Richmond or... back to Berkeley where the friendly folks at Berkel Berkel or the shady looking but delicious Dan Sung Sa (aka Porn Palace) get my business. 

This place has good food. I'm not Korean, so I can't judge on "authenticity" (though the fact that they serve tempura and udon makes me question their "authenticity") but it was tasty nonetheless. The restaurant sort of has a cafeteria feel to it-- I'm probably not explaining it well, but it's just not very chic. It's not dirty in any way, though. 

The BBQ pork and beef are deeelicious, and they're pretty big portions too, so it's likely you'll have leftovers. 
The bibimbap is good too.
author: Saori E.

description: Great place for BBQ.The food is done fresh wile you wait.
author: Steve L.

description: My bf and I randomly came here after driving around trying to find a new place to eat. The food was bland and kind of burnt, but the staff was friendly. Overall experience was ok.
author: Patty L.

description: The mega kabob plate is amazing!!!!  (Especially the beef.)  This place has good prices, serves huge portions, has tasty food, and has a friendly staff.  Definitely going to become a regular.  :)
author: Lainey D.

description:
Me and my girlfriend came here for lunch and it was my first time eating
at Hahns Hibachi, and the food was so yummy, its my new favorite restaurant to eat at now. HIGHLY recommend the stuffed mushrooms!!
author: D N.

description:
I was taken here by a co-worker who served as our Korean BBQ tour guide. She overwhelmed us with information on every dish, but I felt that I should go with the dish with the best name: Bi Bim Bop.

I ordered mine "Sizzling" and with Tofu, meaning it was served fresh off the grill in a clay pot. Bi Bim Bop is a dish that literally means "Mixed Rice" and your toppings include various vegetables, meat/tofu/seafood and a raw egg. The idea, apparently, is to add as much sauce and stir it up, frying the egg and mixing the sauce/veggies. An insider tip is to not scrape the rice off the edge, as this rice can cook for a long time and will serve as a nice, crispy texture.

Needless to say, after my tutorial, I thought the dish was pretty delicious. The location is a bit small and the service is great. If I lived in the neighborhood, I think I would take advantage of take out here more often. 

Until then, I'll dream of bi bim bop.
author: Bryan B.

description:
Here is a quick one. 

Pile-O-Meat

The name says it all.  It is pretty much the only thing I get when I eat here. The dish is very flavorful, never overcooked and extremely filling for the price. One day, I will write my culinary memoirs, and I will name  the first chapter Pile-O-Meat
author: Adam M.

description: love it! yummy hot food with great customer service. the tea is yummy and the spicy pork bulgogi with the great salad and sprout sides keep me coming back for more!!
author: Selina W.

description:
I like to sit outside on a sunny afternoon, sipping a cold Sapporo while waiting for my Bee Bim Bap or BBQ chicken platter. 
I love the Bee Bim Bap cause it comes in sizzling plate and normal. 
The chicken is always delicious!
Oh! and the ribs... YUMMMMMM.
author: Miss C.

description: The beef ribs were scrumptious and well priced. I would definitely go back for them. The Bimibop dish was tasty, but not too heavy. Solid service too.
author: Omar M.

description: What a fabulous and wonderful surprise! Cute and tiny, nice atmosphere, GREAT food, large portion, fantastic price. Yes, yes, just say yes!
author: Sharon C.

description: What I remember of this dinner was I ate some food which was pretty good, but that could be due to impaired judgement. The cops at the next table were cool, well one of them was friendly. Thank you staff for dealing with my loudness. The end.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Let me paint a picture for you all:  My first night in my first apartment in San Francisco.  My new roommates and I finish a long day of moving our crap in.  The heavy lifting required to haul all of my Ikea Dorphenschurgendunkenbergen's up three flights of stairs gave me a mean appetite for some meat on a stick.  

I had no job at the time, so Hahn's was a quick and cheap fix for my carnivorous inclinations.  I made the offer to my new roommates and their boyfriends' to get them something if they so desired, but wisely they declined.  I picked up my food, went back to the new pad and scarfed that shit down.  I went to bed.  I woke up three hours later to:  1.  The sounds of one of my new roommates getting some meat stick of her own, if you know what I mean, and 2.  the sound of my other roommate, her boyfriend, and now one of his friends sitting up watching a movie in the living room, and 3.  the feeling that I was going to give birth to a warm chunky demon child via my mouth. 

However, being the tiny shoebox of an apartment that it was, the bathroom was shared by all, and happened to be in the very center, or hub, of the house, so that all rooms somehow were adjoined to said bathroom.  Therefore I opted to pull a black trash bag full of personal effects (I had run out of boxes, OK?), barely having time to remove its contents, and wrapped it around my head and sealed it off around my neck to then heave up what I believed to be everything I had eaten since I was I was a small child.  And it all came up tasting like charred meat stick.  

I would rather melon-ball my eyeballs out than go back to that place.
author: Lauren S.

description:
Americans pride themselves on being the original grill kings...but au contraire...I beg to differ.  You and your store-bought KC Masterpiece need to shut up!  You're gonna get schooled!  What is it about Korean BBQ that makes it so fekkin' delicioso?  I don't know.  I don't care.  But please don't stop!

From their menu:

****Berzerker Beef Kabobs:  Tender, tasty, Flank Steak, on a skewer.  Scientifically tested by our psychological and executive staff.  Test subjects were observed grunting and viciously defending their plates while eating these kabobs.****

While I did not grunt - I once growled at some chick who was eyeing my last kabob.  And how does one become a member of their psychological and executive staff anyhow?  I want to know...really, I do.

****Meat Mountain:  Well, fellow Meat Crazies, with the Meat Mountain, Meat Truly is everywhere.  "The Meatinator," "Meatarola," "Meat O' Roni," "Meat O' Lux,"  "Beef, Ribs, Chops, Chicken, Pork and a pile O' it.  "Meat@ix.marsnet.com, Gig O' Meat, The last two  are for you High Tech folks.****

Fred Flinstone is really Korean, didn't you know?  A carnivore's delight!.  Side note:  Did a Yelper write their menu?

****BBQ Pork sizzled on the grill just right and slapped on a fresh roll.****

Plain, simple and to the point.  Smack...punch, a kick to the groin - it's that fekkin' good ~ a Mount St. Helens flava eruption.

Say a prayer for North Korea, and smack that idiot leader of theirs with a kabob...just not with mine.  He has hair cooties:  http://ace.mu.nu/archives/Kim_Il_Jong_sm.jpg

A good kabob make me stupid and giddy at the same time!
author: Mc Matty b.

description:
I remember going to this place when I was younger. I use to love the meat mountain. It was a challenge just to finish it, but now when I order the meat mountain. Looks more like a meat speed bump. 

The portions are smaller and meat is no good. No flavor, chewy, and dry. Will not go back to this place again.
author: Peter C.

description: My strong suspicion is that they really only make one dish, but manage to describe it about 20 different ways on a menu that's the size of a small novella.  In any event, everyone seems to have their favorite dish at Hahn's.  Mine is the Mega Deluxe Kebab Plate.  Try it.  You might find that it tastes like your own favorite Hahn's dish...
author: Laurence W.

description:
Good lunch deal! 

The chicken is okay, nothing particularly memorable about it, but the pot stickers? Excellent!!! I definitely recommend the pot stickers! Pot stickers = love. 

I would come here for lunch, but dinner it seems a little pricey for what it is... fast Korean BBQ.
author: Jessica R.

description:
Yesterday after spending some serious quality time on the rowing machine, I had a large hankering for Pork Bulgogi, but I wasn't about to go to Koryo's in Oakland or negotiate the crowds on Saturday night at Brothers in the Richmond. Enter Hahn's, just down the street from Mi Casa (tm).

After checking out the menu I thought "Spicy BBQ Pork " corresponded correctly to Pork Bulgogi, but when I asked the server dude, he said "No, the spices are different, Pork Bulgogi is a different dish!! Incidentally, not anywhere on the menu! Hmmm ...t'was starting to feel like the first time I discovered In-N-Out Burger had a secret menu!

So I got the Pork Bulgogi to go and while it didn't have all the kimchi that you typically expect w/ your BBQ and was a little more expensive for food without all the trimmings, the meat itself was actually rather delicious. I'll definitely be back. 4 Stars!
author: I. O.

description: My boyfriend and I are on the search for the best bibimbop in the city. We've only tried two places so far, but Hans is the hands down winner. The portions are huge, the prices amazing $10/entree, and definitely try the potstickers! The only two downfalls are #1: atmosphere, a little too bright and dingy, but can be overlooked, and #2: they don't serve all of the typical small dishes alongside the bibimbop like most Korean restaurants.
author: callie m.

description:
Well, being a Korean, I will always compare Korean restaurants with that of my mother's cooking. Tough to even compete, and Hahn's doesn't even come close, but wanted to preface the review with that in mind.

I had walked by this place numerous times, and finally decided to step in. The woman who runs the shop is extremely nice and sincere. I ordered the lunch combo, which came with bbq beef, pot stickers, a salad and tempura. (not sure how tempura makes it into a korean restuarant but it was good and I'm a fan of it)

The beef was less than spectacular and grazes what I would call decent. Portions were ok, and the rest of the sides were just mediocre. I could tell the pot stickers and tempura were just heated up from a costco pack probably.

Overall, it was cheap, fast, and the service was nice. Food on the other hand, lacking identity and standard korean flavors)
author: Mike K.

description: After a long day of work, my friends and boss wanted to grab some dinner near Chinatown but not IN Chinatown. The boss suggested a place on Polk and mentioned that this place wasn't bad. The lights were dim and the bathroom had a flower sticker on it.. I don't know why I remember that. There wasn't much people in there, but I kept an open mind. I had a bimbimbop the night before so I decided to order something new. I've been trying to build up my tolerance so I ordered spicy chicken (around $9) and it came with rice and salad, YUM! The chicken wasn't super spicy but it got me huffing! It was a pretty good price and very filling. They have combo meals for $11 which is pretty worth it too! My best friend ordered a bimbimbop and he DRENCHED it with hot sauce. But when I tried it, it was pretty dang good, maybe the hot sauce helped it? Overall, pretty yummy and comfy place! And the waiter was super polite!
author: Linda K.

description:
Whoo BabY!!!!
Ive been eatting here at least every other day!!!!!!
I just really enjoy eatting here..
The staff is great, the food is great, the environment is wonderful!!!
not sure if ill get sick of this place...........
author: Bradley P.

description:
Two words: Bi Bim Bop and  pot stickers...  (oops it that 5 words?)

The prices are right and the food consistently good.  The lunch special is the way to go if you are looking for a great Korean BBQ with all the sides for a reasonable price. 

I have only had one thing I did not like here and it was the lettuce wraps... but everything else has been very good.

The staff of course also keeps me  going back!
author: Jett T.

description:
I love the soft tofu soup here. I have had both the beef and seafood versions. The soup comes from the kitchen literally boiling in the bowl that it is served in. And when you order it spicy hot, they don't fool around. They make it SPICY. It comes with a side of rice, salad and some lightly pickled/salted bean sprouts. 

The guy that owns/runs this place is such a sweetheart too. He is very attentive and always has a smile on his face.
author: ruby h.

description:
My friend Kevin introduced me to Hahn's back in the late 80's and that started my love affair with Korean food, it was the gateway restaurant for the more traditional stuff too.  I used to stop here first on my frequent trips to the city when I lived in Sacramento.   The BBQ chicken was so addictive, there must have been something in the sauce.  I was in heaven when I moved into the neighborhood in 1996 and could eat Hahn's all the time, which I did every day for months.  I have probably eaten everything on the menu but the seafood and vegetarian items.
I was ecstatic when they added the spicy option to the menu.
The spicy meat mountain or pile 'o pork usually satisfy this carnivore's appetite!  Service is always friendly and the food is always good.  I just wish that kimchee was still included without asking for it.
author: Tim O.

description:
Be wary of anybody who tells you Hahn's serves up authentic Korean food.  

The stone bowl bibimbop was passable but there was far too little veggies and beef and far too much rice.  The real offender was the BBQ beef.  It neither tasted nor looked like Korean bbq.  I understand Hahn's is supposed to be fast food style Korean, but still, it was just too much for me to bear.  I'm still cringing.
author: Helen C.

description:
We were returning from grocery shopping and wanted to grab dinner. 
We passed this and went a little ahead, it was very crowded. the next restaurant was almost empty. then we returned to this restaurant and were not disappointed.  Amazing food and amazing service. 

They have good vegetarian options too.
author: Chandrashekar V.

description:
This is a teeny tiny Korean-ish BBQ place. The portions are large & the prices hover around $8 a plate. The spicy BBQ chicken & Bi Bim Bop chicken are tasty for the meat eaters. Non meat eaters, good luck!

If Hahn's was a Spice Girl, it'd be Tangy Spice = yum!
author: Melisser E.

description:
The guy who runs this place, presumably Hahn, is like 7 ft tall. Ok, maybe that's a big exaggeration but you'll recognize him when you walk in. But don't be intimidated - he's very friendly, usually eating with one hand and texting in the other. 

In all fairness, this review isn't so much for Hahn's - but really just their spicy pork dish - which is the first and only thing I've ever ordered. It's awesome. My friend routinely orders the sizzling Bi Bim Bop as well and swears by it. I'm sure it's delicious. 

I also enjoy Hahn's speed. His crew of speedy gonzales Hahn's are quite impressive - which makes take out a breeze.
author: Tom C.

description: i have been coming here for a long time, we love the short ribs, bi bim bop sizzling and tofu soup.  Great neighborhood korean food.
author: kini m.

description: Love this place! Came here on a Saturday night around 9pm and surprisingly they were not busy. They close at 10. I've been to their other location in West Portal a few years back a couple of times and the food is the same as I remembered.  Great BBQ at Reasonable Prices! We ordered the Kabob Combo Platter which had 2 Chicken kabobs, 2 Shrimp kabobs, 1 Beef and 1 Pork kabob with rice, salad and bean sprouts, all for $13.95. It was filling for two! We also ordered the stuffed mushrooms fried in tempura batter for an appetizer. The mushrooms were juicy but the stuffing was dry. All it tasted like was ground pork. We should've gone with the calamari. But the kabobs were grilled perfectly and were flavorful. I also like the sauce that they pour over the bbq.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
I ate at Hahns Hibachi yesterday for supper and really have no serious complaints. 

The restaurant is very airy and roomy. After reading some of the older reviews I guess I lucked out due to a recent expansion. It was clean and comfortable. 

The atmosphere was not very Asian though. I kind of expected some kind of little tidbits to munch on or some tea while I waited for my order but nothing. Also, the server brings me a fork and knife wrapped in a napkin. Now I have nothing at all against napkins. In fact, I'm kind of a huge supporter of napkins. However, I want authenticity when I dine. If I'm having chicken wings I expect to get messy. If I'm having BBQ, I expect a big bottle of BBQ sauce on the table. If I'm having authentic English Fish and Chips, I expect a bottle of malt vinegar on the table. Hahn's must be trying to appeal to us Americans who, in their perception, have not mastered or even reached the advanced level of chopstick technology. That was a disappointment. I had to ask for them. 

I ordered the "Bi Bim Bop". I had no earthly idea what I was getting and that's how I like, Culinary discoveries! My plate arrived and it made me pretty happy to see what I was getting. On the Yelp page for this restaurant you can actually see an order of Bi Bim Bop. It's the plate with the egg in the middle. All those little veggies ringing the plate were nice. the BBQ meat, whatever animal it came from, was tasty as well. They bring you a bottle of BBQ sauce to slather all over whatever you want it on but I would suggest juicing up the meat with it. 

I do want to point out to all you Korean food lovers, contrary to one review there is Bul Go Gi on the menu. 

I'll go back and anyone who finds themselves on Polk in Nob Hill also gets my recommendation to try this place out.
author: Wayne B.

description:
There's really only one thing to get here: sizzling bibimbop (with beef).  Their other menu items are borderline mediocre, but the sizzling bibimbop is fantastic comfort food - warm, salty and a hint of healthy (seasoned cooked spinach, julienned carrots and bean sprouts).  And at the end comes a wonderful surprise: semi-burnt, crunchy rice at the bottom, which you should definitely scrape up off the bowl with your spoon and enjoy.  

Also, the wait staff is super nice and accommodating.  Highly recommend if you're in the area and looking for a stomach-warming meal.
author: E. C. P.

description:
Why is Hanh's Hibachi so grubb'n? Just when I thought this tastiness couldn't get any better, I tried the crispy rice in the hot iron bowl, suggested by the waiter.

He, by the way, is like... 6'4... and so well spoken you would think he belonged at a pricey joint.

Really small space - but very cozy. No fuss with fancy decor, but super clean and welcoming. I wish I lived around the corner. But then I'd be 100 pounds heavier.
author: Charmagne L.

description: Bi bim bop was really and would highly recommend it. Its a small spot so if your going in a group it might not work out. But if there is no around go for it!
author: Erick I.

description:
Also been to Oakland and Marina locations, but I must say this place is the best. I wouldn't call this Korean BBQ though because it doesn't taste like one, so I call it "their BBQ" and I like "thier BBQ". 

The taste is pretty simple and straight forward. Nothing sophisticated. Some might get tired of the taste half way through but it is still good food. 

The best thing about this place is that happy people work here. They treat you with a big smile and it always makes me feel good.
author: Kaku Y.

description:
Stopped in on a Saturday afternoon and got a lunch special to go.  It came with teriyaki chicken, rice, fried pot stickers, and a little salad.  All was good and it was a good value.  I'll be back to try more.

Cashier was very polite.
author: King D M.

description:
Apparently, I reviewed the wrong Hibachi.  That night with the crazy group was the one on Steiner.  I came to this one yesterday for lunch.

Oh, it was so good!  I ordered the soft tofu soup with beef and it came with a side of rice, salad and bean sprouts - my favorite Korean side!  The soup was medium spicy and it really hit the spot.  This is too far to walk from my office, but if someone was driving, I'd buy.  It's great comfort food.
author: Lynnie P.

description: I ate year once many years ago.  When I walked in, there was no Korean person in sight to take my order.  That should have been my cue to walk out,   I ordered the galbi rice plate...(bbq short ribs for those who don't know).  It was a bit more expensive..yet worse than Sorabol.  My food came, it wasn't a marinade....it was gravy....probably the worst interpretation of Korean food I have ever ate.  The people running this spot don't know squat about Korean food.  If any of my friends ever want to eat here, I will break their nose.
author: A L.

description:
Soon Tofu was surprisingly pretty good.  I suppose I was surprised because I think of Hahn's Hibachi as a fast food restaurant.  But then its $9 for soon tofu so it ain't fast food prices...  
Just remember, no ban chan and you have to pay for kim chi.  You have to pay for kim chi at a korean restaurant!  shock.
author: Wakako U.

description:
I've lived near this place for years, but was never attracted to it. But a couple Fridays ago I was too lazy to walk far for food, and wanted something other than my usual delivery places. I called in an order; Pork Spare Ribs for my boyfriend, BBQ beef for me and a calamari appetizer.

It was ready in about 10 minutes--I'll give it a point for being quick. The tempura calamari was disgusting. Calamari is one of my favorite foods, but I couldn't choke down the rubbery crap they were passing off as calamari.  

The salad that came with my takeout order was HOT...hot iceberg lettuce and shredded carrots does not equally a yummy start to a meal. I moved on to my beef, which was stringy and barely edible. The rice was equally bland. I don't know how rice gets bland, but this was, even with the BBQ sauce. 

My boyfriend was nice enough to give me a couple bites of the ribs, which were tasty enough, but fatty.

Overall it's far too pricy for the low, low quality. I am not impressed and will not return.
author: Lara L.

description:
I can't believe this place is rated so highly. Hahn's Hibachi is cheap-ass, fake-ass Korean BBQ. Personally, I'm not Korean. But I have a knack for being able to tell if a restaurant is authentic or not. Hahn's is total bullshit. Each of their menu items is completely generic and watered down (so they can make sure to serve the same dish at every location). There's nothing good about the meat, they just slop the sauce on. I've been to neighborhood Korean BBQ places that could run circles around this place.

This location is particularly lame. There's absolutely no room inside. You have to sit elbow to elbow with the other customers and the employees are constantly standing 2 feet away from you (which makes it difficult to talk shit while you're there).

I don't what it is, hypnotism or hysteria, but most people seem to love these places. Don't be fooled.
author: Adam R.

description: This is one of my favorite spots. I have never been disappointed here. The BBQ chicken is to die for. The plate comes with salad and rice.  The restaurant itself is pretty small so we usually order for takeout. Two people can eat for just about $20. I must admit the food portions are not as large as before BUT it's still good, When we do eat in , they always give out a stick of flavored GUM! Sounds silly but even the Gum is good.
author: karen g.

description: Stopped in for lunch yesterday because we were already in the neighborhood. We got the not sizzling bi bim bop and an order of beef tofu soup.  Both dishes were decent though pretty americanized.  A nice place to go if you want Korean in the neighborhood, but definitely not a new favorite. Oh and service was excellent.
author: Lisa C.

description:
I always get the Chicken Bi Bim Bop and never had even the slightest reason to complain. Food's good, prepared fresh, prices are reasonable. 

It can get a bit chilly in here, but if you are daring, close the window above the door like we did one evening. Not ten seconds later, one of the guys behind the counter rushed towards us and asked whether he should seat us at a different, less breezy table and if he could open the window just a little bit. To prevent people in the kitchen dying from heat stroke, I assume - hooray for safe workplace laws.

Sure, might not be 100 percent authentic, but I guess you would get that in Korea. And I sure can't walk there in five minutes.
author: Roland A.

description:
Yum... Riiiiibs.

Big-ass beef spare ribs. Or maybe some short ribs? or maybe some pork ribs? or maybe some chicken? or maybe... you get the picture.

Korean food has never been something i knew much about, but after my buddies took me here for lunch, i was hooked. The prices are fair and the food is fresh and prepared well. It's totally yummy.

If the plates offered on the menu are too small for your appetite (like me), they will let you add extra ribs or an extra piece of chicken for only a couple bucks more.

I'm not one for Kim chi, or whatever those pickled onions are on my plate, but the salad dressing they use on the modest iceburg patch on your plate is super good, and oh my... Did i mention the ribs ??? :P

Young Korean Dude who runs it is a nice guy too. It's family operated and usually one of the clan can be spotted in their tiny kitchen, choring away.

Hahn's on Polk is small, with 5 tables, so consider taking it to go if it's during the busy part of dinner time....
author: The Shmooze ..

description:
This is a glorified teriyaki joint, that calls itself a Korean BBQ restaurant so that they can charge you two extra dollars per entree.  The meats are pretty good; I thought their chicken was better than their beef.  Their hot stone bibimbop was mushy and tasteless.  The japchae noodles were overcooked, and the whole thing just tasted like sesame oil and salt.  And don't expect banchan, the various side dishes that come with all korean meals.  I had to ask (and pay extra) for the kimchee.

I'd come back for the chicken/rice entrees.  For traditional korean, I rather trek out to Richmond or Japantown and pay a little extra.
author: Cathy S.

description:
First off, the service was tops.  The girl that was taking orders and bringing food to people.. she was on top of it!~!!!

Food was good and quick.  I ate it all.  I ordered any 2 bbq items.

Price was decent.. bekuz the portions were big!!!!!

Decent amount of dishes available.
author: Roger A.

description:
This was an overall fun experience.
 
 So I'm just about decided on my order when my waitress starts screaming with joy in the kitchen - something about 1000 dollars.
It seems that she's won $1000 on a scratcher and she runs out of 
the restaurant to collect. I ask "wow, she won a thousand dollars?"
The kid behind the counter tells me that it was actually one of the 
cooks. It was an example of the vibe that she was so excited for one 
of the cooks who couldn't speak English that won the money and ran
out to collect for him - very selfless. Unfortunately I had a selfish thought ( that's cool but I'm starvin. looks like I'm not gonna be 
ordering for a bit). I was over it though and happy for the cook.
Just then the kid behind the register who I thought was just a busboy proceeded to take my order.

  Then there's the highly eccentric customer that had been eatin ribs
on sidewalk table. With my inside window seat this guy became a 
great source of entertainment. He began interacting with every pedestrian passing. From Tenderloin bum slum to Marina snobby
wanna be Hollywood girls he attempted to befriend. I gotta admit
dude was a freaky, dorky , kinda annoying guy. I felt for his sidewalk
victims but I highly enjoyed his antics. End result : He's spinning his
hula hoop down street( what the hell is he doing with a hula hoop?
-hehe!) at pedestrians and while waiting for it to roll back he busts 
into a B-boy stance. I wanted to roll around the restaurant floor 
laughing.

 Oh yeah- the food.
I love BBQ, so it isn't gonna be hard to please my taste buds.
I ordered the traditional spiced spicy BBQ chicken.
 It was really good, although my high tolerance for spice
had me craving a little more heat. Good flavor though-
definitely goin back.
author: Josh H.

description: I am a big fan of Korean BBQ so when I came across this restaurant I was quite excited.  I ordered the super rib combination and it was a lot of meat.  I took it to-go.  When I got back to my office, I was disappointed.  There is a lot of meat, but it just wasn't delicious to me.  The pork ribs were overcooked and dry.  The beef ribs were ok.  The short ribs were the best but I've had better.
author: Brent T.

description: This place is a pretty solid Koren bbq. Not the best I've had, but it's pretty cheap and food comes out fast. The sauce for my seafood pan saute was a little watery and could have been a lot more flavorful, but it wasn't bad. Although my friend's chicken kebab looked amazing. Definitely a good place to come check out if you're just kickin it on Polk, but I wouldn't try to make a night out of it.
author: Nikki P.

description:
The absolute best chicken and beef bbq sandwiches.  Juicy chunks of meat, smothered in cheese and wrapped in a soft cloud of a white bread roll. I usually order one of each and some of those yummy fried mushrooms.  I try my best to finish it all, but my eyes are always bigger than my tummy (so far...thank god). 

I've had the combo platters too, but the sandwiches are my favorite.
author: Jennifer G.

description: I love this place.  When I lived in the hood back in the early 90's I use to go here a lot.  Now I live a bit more away, but love to go back -- good value, good food, friendly service.  What more can you ask for?  YUM!
author: David M.

description: The beef was horrible the worst ever, everything else was good except the christmas music which cost me 20$ to get them to turn off, service was fast and friendly and they let me drink my own bottle in the restaraunt which was great.
author: Kyle J.

description: Hate to do this.  They were very friendly but the food was terrible.  We did not even eat our food.  The egg rolls taste like frozen egg rolls.  The quality of meat poor and the shrimp was nasty and had tails on it.  We were turned off.
author: John K.

description: The lunch special was good value but the actual quality and flavor of the food was okay. My pork was too burnt and didn't taste that good.
author: Amanda L.

description: I love Hahn's lunch special #1 - spicy chicken BBQ, 2 potstickers, 2 tempura shrimps, yummy salad with miso dressing, sprouts (maybe pickled) and rice all for a happy $8, it's cheap eats at their best.  I can't argue with this price or the amount of food...you'll burn it off walking up the hill.
author: Amy W.

description: Good flavors, good prices, decent ambiance, decent service. First time I've had Korean in a while. My family liked the lunch special except for the chicken junta, which tasted like a sausage patty from McDonalds.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Reliable! They have never net me down and it's been many years. From the bright "hulloooo" when you walk in to the consistently good food, I BBQ (like saying heart for a guy) Hahn's on Polk.

Like most others say, not the most authentic, but they do things right here - no questions asked. Some recommendations you ask?

- The lunch special for sure. $8 and you'll be happy full - meat, tempura shrimp and Chix Jun. Werd
- Bibimbop, but not the sizzling.
- Stuffed Mushrooms - ohh man these are good!
- Mixed kabobs or BBQ Pork entrees
- Kim Chee - I like their cabbage recipe
author: Mike C.

description:
I come here on occasion.  The food's usually good and filling.  The prices aren't bad either.

They just expanded into the space next door as well so seating's not limited to their very very small dining room alone.  The new decor's much cleaner and nicer too.  Seems they REALLY like those tiffany-style craftsman lamps.  

On to the food.  Usually, Korean restaurants give you a LOT of those little dishes of stuff to go with your meal.  Not so with this place (at least not on the few lunch trips I took here).  A bit disappointed by that.

Otherwise, pretty good portions for what you get.  For my latest venture, I had the Bi Bim Bop (combination rice bowl).  The egg on top was raw, but since I chose it in a sizzling bowl, it was no big deal getting cooked in there.  Tasty stuff.

Service can only be described as "it's there".  The wait person was efficient, but she had no problem grabbing a plate of food from someone already eating and shoving it in front of another person at the same table after realizing that she made a mistake.
author: Winnie C.

description:
Really more of a 3.5, but I'll lean to the left today...

Food is decent.  I've gotten food from here (never sat down there) a bunch of times and have never gotten sick.  Not sure if they just had a bad batch of beef/chicken/whatever for a while, from a bunch of other reviewers, but no gastrointestinal  problems here...  

The meat is sometimes a bit dry and drowned in the BBQ sauce, other times it's been nice and juicy.  The jap chae and bi bim bop are okay - not great, but decent enough (not like there's a lot of choice in the area).

If  you like fried stuff, I'd suggest the stuffed mushroom appetizer - it's mushrooms, stuffed with slices of beef, then fried.  Mushrooms with beef!  It's as ingenious as Snakes on a Plane.
author: T C.

description:
The "huz" and i have eaten here for years, it's also a great place to take people visiting, it's small, it's not too spicy, and it's just great grilled meat.  I have a very weak stomach and have never had any problem, nor have any of my soft-pawed friends from the Midwest.

The stuffed mushrooms (tempura) are actually stuffed with minced steak, excellent, so vegans beware.  The combo tempura is a wonderful mix of jalapenos tempurah (same minced steak), shrimp, mushrooms, etc.

We go here STARVING after a super workout and get the combo tempurah and the mixed grill and split everything.

For just regular lunch we get the special, cheap and lots of food, chicken in our fave.  Pork/beef is good but I don't like it so thin sliced, reminds me of Arbys.

Bi Bim Bop is good but too much carbs for me personally, not enough meat.  We're fags, so when it comes to meat and protein, can you ever get enough?
author: Enzo L.

description:
Gave this place a try for dinner before a show at the Red Devil Lounge across the street the other day. It was about what I expected, decent, large portions of middle-of-the road korean bbq. Not bad, but not exceptional either. I had the chicken bi-bim-bop. The chicken was good, although it was a little bland and there wasn't enough of it. The veggies were quite good and fresh, but there was too much rice. Drowned in hot-sauce, it tasted good enough and filled me up. But for 10$ I expect more meat and less rice. I could hit up Sorabol at the mall for half the price and roughly the same quality. But it's Polk Street so I guess it's relatively reasonable.

My friend got the combo meal with a variety of skewered meats. It looked pretty good, and I'd probably order something like that next time at Hahn's. The server was also quite friendly and attentive, despite the fact that he was the only one working a very crowded (albeit quite small) room.

All in all, a satisfying but unremarkable meal. I'd probably go back at some point, but with so many other restaurants to try in this area, I won't be rushing back to Hahn's.
author: Brian H.

description:
What happened to this place???!!!  In the early 90's I used to frequent this place religiously as the quality of the food was superb: 5 stars in taste and 5 stars for value.  Today, I decided to come here to satisfy my KBBQ fix (my first time in 5 years) and I was disappointed to say the least.  

The chicken portions used to be much bigger and you used to get free kimchee!  Now, the chicken is thinly sliced (just like the beef) and engorged in sauce!   The kimchee has been replaced with lame iceberg lettuce salad!  Oh man, I hate to say it, but Sorabol in Stonestown is better than this... and it's less expensive!  True!
author: Larry A.

description:
I'd say this is like a Korean "Fast Food" Joint.  Not Fast Food as in the food is ready as soon as you order it.  But what I mean is that most Korean restaurants I go to are like full service restaurants at full service prices.  

This place is more informal and with lower prices too.  Maybe a better description of this place is that it is like your neighborhood Taqueria but minus the burritos and plus the Korean BBQ....  A good concept that works based on their many locations.
author: Mark W.

description:
I've been eating at Hahn's Hibachi for many years but haven't been there lately until last week.  I must say that the food is still tasty and fresh.  The prices went up a little and the portions got a little thinner.  But hey, that's everywhere nowadays. I used to always get the Pork Spare Ribs (Spicy) but this time ordered the BBQ Chicken (Spicy). My friend had the Tofu Soup which came with rice.  Overall the meal was good.  
Oh, the one on Polk Street has just been remodeled so it's kinda spacious and holds twice as many people than before cuz they expanded their place.  If you check out the pic, imagine double the size to the left.

Good Eatings
author: gordon g.

description: Polk street is my usual weekdays lunch to dinner stomping grounds, and this place is ok. I wouldn't tell a friend to eat here of all korean places in the city to try. Imagine if you will, eating the best burger in the world made by some kind of iron chef, then eating at mc donalds. This place would be the mc donalds of korean food, it serves it's purpose for those starving students. You also have to pay for kimchi which I'm not down with since you could buy a facking Jar the size of my head for two servings of the kimchi they offer.
author: Jon I.

description:
LOVE HAHN'S...the food is to die for!

The setting is not super fancy but the food is definitely good.  I used to get the bbq chicken but I've upgraded and got the spicy bbq chicken.  I love the sides, the bean sprouts are awesome and if you can handle kimchee, replace the side salad and get the kimchee instead.

This place always has Orangina, so that's a plus!

Prices are very reasonable for the portions, about $7-8 for a huge portion of bbq chicken with the two side vegetables and rice.

Eat in or take out, very convenient for local Nob Hill/Polk St. folks.
author: Winnie L.

description:
So, I'm conflicted about this place.  On one level, it should be worse than it is.  I mean, this is the McDonalds of Korean  BBQ, write?  I should be offended by the shortcuts, no?

Here's what they get right - the meats are cooked over an open flame grill -   Like Burger King claims they do, but at Hahns, you can actually see them work the grill (not a microwave).  This creates a fairly legit meat product.  Also, their kimchi is actually pretty good.  No watered down fermented in Sprite BS like some fast food places (cough Sarabol cough)...

Here's what they get wrong - kimchi is extra, i.e. not included with your meal deal.  I assume this is in deference to their non-korean audience, but give SF some credit.  I think people ordering Korean BBQ know that kimchi is part of the deal.  You don't have to give them that mayo salad crap.  Give us the stink!
author: Andrew C.

description:
Ahhh..the "batch" as I like to call it. 

If you need good, quick korean, this is the place. Good Tofu soup, good pork dishes.

Good prices, good food. BBQ is good, salad is my favorite!

So hit up the "batch" if you're grubbin for Korean!
author: Eddy N.

description:
We hit this place up one Friday night because I knew nothing about Korean BBQ and therefore wanted to try it.

It is very small and tucked away on Polk and Clay and the food definitely makes up for the very basic ambiance of the place.  

There were also a number of folks who seemed to be returning to the spot, including a Korean couple, 2 cops, and a gangster and his ho.

I ordered a mango snapple and the Beboppin' Bibimbop , which was excellent, despite the fact that the tiny red peppers in the sauce tore up my insides.  The boyfriend ordered the pork chops and they were also out of this world.  Both dishes came with a side salad with delicious miso dressing and steamed rice and bean sprouts.  They also bring the most delicious lime gum (if I remember correctly) when they bring the check.

I think everyone left happy.
author: Hannah A.

description:
Hahn's Hibachi or "It is what it is"

While this place is not as diverse/authentic/traditional as other Korean places in SF, it manages to put out some really decent and cheap dishes in an unassuming atmosphere, with some lovely service. I would recommend this place if you're in a hurry/economically challenged/craving korean flavors and on Polk St. Nuff said.
author: Libby T.

description:
I always take Han's to-go, and it is always fabulous. Love the lunch specials with the BBQ chicken, beef or pork accompanied with fluffy rice, seasoned mung beans and jai yun. Spicy ain't too spicy, but lacks the original flavor of the plain BBQ sauce. So if you like it spicy, get the regular and add your own spice at home (it's rooster sauce for me!)

And, do order the vegetable tempura, it is one of the best in the city!
author: Jane I.

description:
Lots of meat for not a lot of dollar!
My girlfriend often orders something like 'bit bim bum' which looks nice but it's the Meat Mountain for me!
Clean place and can almost always get a seat straight away.
author: Dan C.

description:
bi bim bop + tofu = awesome
shrimp kebabs = good
veggie rolls = fair

will i come back? = yes
did i think the tall waiter kristel s. mentions was cute? = yes.

+1
author: Lindsay T.

description:
Don't expect something fancy. Hahn's is quick, casual Korean food. You don't get to grill your own food (I'm convinced it tastes better when I get to grill) nor get tons of free side dishes as in the nicer places.

But the food here is pretty good. I can always smell the yummy BBQ smells coming from Hahn's. I agree Hahn's is a tad bit on the expensive side for something in the take-out genre but not enough for me to stop coming.

Pot stickers come with a sweet sesame sauce with a kick! A must try!
J was a fan of the tempura mushrooms though I thought it had a little too much batter.

Was torn b/w the regular beef and spicy so got half-and-half. The clear winner is spicy! They pour a sauce over the regular which gives it most of it's taste.
author: Princess Pompom Patootie W.

description:
Minus one star for no kimchee with the meals!

This is probably the best take out restaurant in the Nob Hill area. Good food, ample portions, and good service. There are better Korean restaurants around SF, but you can't beat Hahn's for the convenience.
I like the "Meat Mountain".  The place is even better, now that they expanded.
author: Collin W.

description: No free small dishes. Was charged $1.75 for tea. The stone pot dish lacked flavor. The ones on Geary are much better.
author: YM L.

description:
I like the food and have gone there routinely for 1.5 years since I work nearby. Total of maybe 100 times. The waitress knew me after 20 times. 
The young waitress is fantastic. The older shorter one offended me enough to write this.  I finished my meal and the she was very busy. Knowing the price, I left what I thought was sufficient money on the table and left. The next time I was in, she snapped at me that I was short a dollar last time. I did not mind being informed that I made a mistake but I resent the accusatory tone. If this is how you treat loyal customers?...Forget you. I have left more in tip the last time before that alone. Short term greed....
author: Dietmar B.

description: I must say I've eaten about 10 years and the Oakland jack London square location..the food is always fresh and such a value at lunch or dinner...I mean
author: Athena C.

description: Friendly, family-owned restaurant with delicious bibimbap and soft tofu soup. The combo dinners have generous portions. A good value.
author: Janice L.

description:
Mmmm...Korean BBQ is one of my favorites!!  A friend of mine is in town for a few days and we just happened to stumble onto this place.

I was pleased we found it!  The potstickers were yummy.  They flash fry them I believe.  Whatever they did, they were yum yum..

I had the BBQ beef and it's something I rarely eat.  But there is nothing I love more than Korean BBQ!!  I love my heart, but I HAD to do it:)

The beef was tender and a tad fatty, but don't discount it on that fact.  Fat = flavah dahling!!
The salad dressing was great, too!  My friend had the rib combo plate.  Finished it and LOVED it.  

Service was excellent and not pushy at all.  Even when we pushed our stay to closing and a bit after 10pm.  Thanks for being patient for two long time friends.

Check 'em out!!
author: Kat M.

description:
I have come here a few times - the food is good and the portions are the right size. Although I do not count it as among the best Korean restaurants - those are found in Koreatown in LA.

The spicy chicken is my go-to dish here and has a pretty good kick to it. Although its not a rooster sauce kick I have come to love. The sprouts on the side are always a treat and whenever I ask for extra they are happy to oblige. 

Some people seem to complain about the service but I have found it to be great every time. My friends and I have stayed beyond closing time on occasion and the owner/servers have never kicked us out or given us dirty looks.

+1 star for the servers' ability to remember your entire order without writing it down. I am not talking about 1 or 2 people but a group of 7 or 8 with a bunch of special orders.
author: Arin N.

description:
I've been to Hanh's before and had pretty decent results. I ordered take out earlier today because I was craving some Korean food. As the closest (and only) Korean restaurant in the neighborhood, it wins by default

The food today was very underwhelming. I ordered a combo plate of spare ribs and short ribs which came with rice, small salad and bean sprouts.
-short ribs were ok- cooked well but under-spiced
-spare ribs were terrible! they were slathered with a gelatinous sauce which was awful! I was really surprised at how bad this was - stay away.
-salad was simple, and the dressing was good. very small though
-bean sprouts weren't good either! they weren't fresh or crisp, no good!

Based on this experience, I know to not order take out from Hanh's anymore. Since it is the only Korean nearby, it will probably still win by default if I am in need of quick bi bim bap or kbbq. Just avoid the take out...
author: VL K.

description: Pretty good food. I had the bibimbap which was really good and sizzling in the pot. the prices are a little on the high side for my taste. i found a piece of a staple in my bibimbap and showed it to the waiter who was very nice and didn't charge me for it. The service is really good. I also have had pile of meat here which was good too.
author: P D.

description:
4 stars it gets, because yay!! I am definitely a fan!!! I have spent some time in Korea and although the barbecue here can't be said to be that traditional it is pretty good. 

The most important bit, what I come for and what makes me skip a little in happiness is the Bi Bim Bop, sizzling of course, and the Tofu soup spicy of course, which as a side note is good for any cold, flu or R Bar  based hangover.
author: Alex H.

description:
it used to be a tiny place that seated only less than 20 people but they just expanded the place next door and now it doesn't feel so clostaphobic.

Big portions and great prices, come eat at 11am-3pm weekdays and sat and the lunch speical are 7.95. 
Minus one star for not being real Korean food, it's more like Americanlize korean bbq than the real deal but at the prices and portions, who cares
author: P.V. H.

description:
Yum yum! Spicy BBQ chicken! 
i never had spicy chicken that was actually spicy!!!!!it was the best spicy chicken i ever had.. and that was what sparked my love for korean food!!! :] the price is a bit high but sooo worth it! i needa make my way here again!!!!!!!!

-x3 shells
author: Lily X.

description: The BBQ Beef lunch special was a tasty lunch, but authentic Korean flavor was lacking somewhat.
author: Duke K.

description: This is 1 of my fav spots. U gotta try the super appetizer combo, its fried...that's stuffed jalapeño, stuffed mushroom , and tempura shrimp. If u like meat they have a meat mountain dish it just has hella meat with rice. It's good. The seafood salad is slamm too it has a miso dressing. Mmm mmm mm.
author: Mark H.

description:
we were visiting some friends and we ate at Hahn's.  i was excited to see korean ladies running the place and expected more.

i had the chap chae and it was the worst i've ever had.  my girl liked the chicken, mandoo, and lettuce wrap.   but did say that the beef was too marinated.

it's okay.....
author: izumi n.

description: I just checked my credit card statement today, and it seems like they have added an additional $2 to my credit bill.  I placed cash on the table, but I guess the cashier didn't realize that, and put in more. MAKE SURE YOU PAY WITH CASH so they do not rip you off, just like they did to me. Not sure if it's worth it to contact my credit card company, but just dont think this is very ethical for a restaurant to do.
author: David S.

description: This is an alright starting point for people that kinda want to try Korean food but are too scared of the real thing.  The menu mostly consists of yawnfest stir-frys, but check out the small "authentic" section of the menu.  You'll get a mild, safe version of what you'd end up getting at a real Korean joint.  If you can handle these "authentic" dishes then it's time to step it up and go to Seoul Garden or My Tofu House.
author: Victoria G.

description: The lunch deal here is a great value- tons of food, cheap, and bagged up to go in minutes.  Unfortunately it's not all that great and salty as all hell.  But if you're in a hurray, broke  and starving you can do a lot worse.  Just make sure you have tons of water handy.
author: phil h.

description: The layout always turned me off because its small and cold, not small and cozy.  I recently discovered the Beboppin' Bibimbop with beef (!).    She bop--he bop--a--we bop I bop--you bop--a--they bop Be bop--be bop--a--lu--she bop
author: T-Bone L.

description:
i think one plate of food can feed 3 people, no joke. 

hahn's hibachi is like the panda express of korean restaurants. it's reasonably priced and fills you up, but with all of the other really truly great korean bbq's around this city, i'd much rather spend my money elsewhere.
author: May T.

description:
Y'all this is my first WORST dining experience in SF...As you well know- I travel down on the Polk Corridor to RH from yoga...well I stopped by this place with my friend who raved about this place- one she and her bf use to frequent... We ordered different combo plates- hers with chicken and mine with beef...The meal arrived hot and with a side salad...I grabbed my cell phone to answer my call- and was about  to take my first bite off the salad when I saw something crawling over it!!!
Yes it was a little roach...mind u it wasnt one but TWO!!!
I got off the phone and pointed to my friend what was on my lunch meal...Needless to say, we let the server know who immediately  removed my platter...My friend lost her appetite- the server comped my meal but not my friend's...Havent had korean bbq since then :-( 
AND after reading some yelper's comments about this place- wellllll here's a plausible cause???
author: Arissa C.

description: Some of the best- authentic Korean BBQ you can get in the city.  Everything on their menu is delicious, fresh, and totally inexpensive.  My favorite is the sauteed chicken and vegetables (extra broccoli)- medium spice, served over a mound of steamed rice- it's delicious!! and there's enough on the plate for 2 meals!!  And this location is definitely the best one, but you really can't go wrong with Hahn's.
author: Shanti G.

description: One of my favorite places to go eat at lunch in Nob Hill. Good food and pleasant atmosphere. First time I was just looking for something new and different, having never tried Korean cuisine I knew that this was the right kind of place. Service is fast, my food is always prepared with in 5 minutes of ordering. I like coming back for seconds to this place.
author: Jaswinder S.

description: Smaller and less friendly than the Noe Valley location, but the food is just as good. As previously noted, Beboppin' Bibimbop - a wonderful combo of either barbecued chicken, pork, or beef mixed with crunchy stir-fried vegetables and a fried egg - is de bomb. Take home either Meat Mountain or Pile 'o' Pork and feed a family of four.
author: Gourmet G.

description: Pile of Pork sounds awesome and it was indeed a decent plate of meat. However, the place is surprisingly expensive compared to places that have similar foodstuffs. From a Hawaiian food P.O.V. I'd choose L&L because it's cheaper. From a Korean food POV I would got with an authentic korean BBQ joint like Brother's or similar.
author: Jeff L.

description: The City is peppered with these restaurants -- there's one in Noe Valley, at West Portal, and on Irving Street, among others, and it is a really pleasant venue for good, consistent Korean barbecue. I like this one on Polk, although it's rather small, so if you're adverse to cuddling with your dining neighbors, you might be happier taking it to go if they look crowded. My fave is the amazing Spicy BBQ Beef plate. And don't be a Nancy boy (or Tommy girl) -- ask for chopsticks so you can eat your meal properly!
author: Gregor G.

description: Great atmosphere.  Tall Korean waiter (I was tripping over my tongue until I saw the ring...) was great.  Our eyes were WAY bigger than our stomachs, but everything was fantastic.  Tempura was yummy.  All the meats were tasty (we had samplers, so a little of everything fabulous).  I'd go again, but its really no where near where I live, and parking in this neighborhood is notoriously difficult.
author: Kristel S.

description: What can I say.  Great food at a great price.  Super friendly and fast service.  The B-B-Q beef is my fave and the potstickers rock!
author: Mike F.

description:
mister hahn. why do i have to smell like my bi bim bop when i leave? (it's not very good for my game) and don't you think it's funny that you serve sapporo in hite glasses? (as an observant friend of mine pointed out)

tasty tasty meaty food when you're hungry, but with all of the other choices on polk, i don't know if i'll be picking you again mister hahn!
author: Diana L.

description: I had a boyfriend who used to love this place.  It was a sign that he was not worth keeping.  Poor quality meat.  The only thing it has going for it is the price-and if that's your main focus, use the Chron's Cheap Eats list or Chowhound for ideas.  Ramen noodles might be a better choice.
author: Beth V.

description: I probably don't know what real Korean food is like.  However, whatever food this place serves is actually tasty - and plentiful.  I always get the stuffed mushrooms, tempura veggies, and BBQ pork or chicken.  Their gravy is incredible.  Their udon is also very good.  Have been going here for years and they just expanded their dining room.
author: R F.

description: LOVE THIS PLACE, THE FOOD IS GREAT. Been going here for 20 + years. Whenever I get a chance I eat here.
author: Kimberly Q.

description: Food is good, service is OK.  I got the all meat dish and it was a good amount and it was pretty spicy which is how I like it.  It's affordable and tasty - although it doesn't compare to some of the places out on Geary.
author: Marian G.

description: If you're about quantity this place is for you. Doesn't taste like authentic korean though. I made the mistake of trying this place out with my mom and we were both disappointed! The portions are huge but really doesn't taste like korean food. The worst part is that they don't give ban chan! Come on! Boooooooooooooo!
author: Lin L.

description: I was actually lured into this place by the smell which was meat-tastic. I have eaten here quite a few times and have not really loved anything except the sizzling bi bim bop, which is actually quite tasty and craveable. I'm a little annoyed that they charge for kimchee and that when I order spicy food it is never spicy enough (I know I look like I can't handle anything hotter than salt, but I'm a spice queen), but it's a good place to eat when you need a cheap, fast meal. Oh, and I love that they have dish names like "Meat Mountain" and "Pile O' Beef."
author: Rebecca H.

description: Decent food at decent prices. I prefer Korea House in SC, but I wouldn't put them in the category. The guys working that night were really nice. And everything was made to order, so that was nice, too. I would come back again, only if the other restaurants in the area were packed.
author: Mary T.

description: I don't know much about Korean food, except for what I read.  I really want to try a lot, but all the things I want to try, they don't have.  I guess becuase its bbq.  But I really like the chicken jun.  It's just so good.  It melts in your mouth like liquid happyness.  So I'll keep coming as long as they have chicken jun.
author: Red F.

description: Spicy means spicy. Zero atmosphere but good eats and attentive service. I love the spicy pork. Good spot to fill the tummy before a night of drunkenness.
author: Kate S.

description: Boo. Hiss. Hahn's you've done me right a time or two, but you've done me wrong for the last time. Thanks for the completely inadequate lunch experience. It was really cool the way you made us wait for 15 minutes before taking our order. It was even cooler when you gave our order to someone else who had come in after us. After that it was another 15-20 minutes before we actually got food. My favorite part is when you gave me beef instead of chicken. No wait wait, my absolute favorite part is when my boyfriend noticed hairs (yes plural, hairS) in his food. I won't be back.
author: Jessica R.

description: I was walking down Polk street and stumbled on this spot. I then took a look at some reviews and decided to give it a try, I am glad I did. The spicy chicken barbecue I had was off the hook. The only drawback was that the poor owner was taking calls serving food running the register you know just doing to much. Overall good place
author: Manuel D.

description:
i asked if they had bulgogi (bbq beef) with jap chae (clear glass noddles), and i was told, "no."  so i'm like, okay, let me order two separate dishes of each.  when they came, my bulgogi had jap chae in it.  so now i have tons of clear glass noddles.  wtf.  and the waitress speaks english, so it definitely was not a language barrier.

also, the bulgogi was drenched in a watery mess.  it was disgusting.  i thought it was bbq beef.  why does it look like my beef was steamed or even boiled and drenched in water?  

i also got their veg tempera because i read a review here that it was really good.  when i tried it, it was far from "the best tempera in the city" as that review stated.  

it was really expensive too.  the bf ordered a "meat mountain," and along with everything i ordered, the total came to be over 55$.  and we only had water and those dishes.

it would have been two stars, except it was so expensive, it'll only receive one.  i'll definitely never return.
author: H. L.

description: Ehh, not the best Hahn's.  Go to the one in Castro or even better, go to the one in Oakland.  The BBQ beef short ribs is not as tasty as the other restaurants, they SKIMP on the number of ribs (they serve three pieces whilst the others serve four or more), and they don't even include kimchee or pickled cucumbers!  Huh?  No kimchee????
author: Allie C.

description: SOOOO GOOD!  I love their soups (Beef Udon) and their rib plates!  Their staff is friendly and I noticed that they remodeled the place which looks great.  I highly recommend trying this spot out!
author: Maria E.

description:
I think I should give Hahn's Hibachi another try (third time is, as the saying go, the charm), because in reviewing the somewhat hilarious online menu, I'm left thinking that I really should like the place.  

I've had the Veggie Tofu Kabobs, which are, "veggie good and beautiful too, and good for you."  But I don't know if I agree.  

Of course I've never had the Meat Mountain, or the Pile 'o Pork, but they sound pretty damn amazing.  (Right?  Don't they?)  Nor have I tried the Berzerker Beef Kabobs, which are "scientifically tested by our psychological and executive staff."   (Psychological staff!) 

So once I go off this 13-year vegetarian thing I've got going on, I'm definitely going to give one of the many scientifically tested menu items at Hahn's a try.  Then maybe I can join the "first pork fan club in America," which Hahn's menus claims was started by Hahn's customers.
author: Hannah J.

description: I'm not sure how authentic this place is but it's very affordable and the portions are large. The menu is simple but yummy. You definitely feel as though you got your monies worth.
author: Melinda Q.

description: This place may be a chain-- well in the Bay area at least, but I love it. Their food never disappoints, it is always satisfying and the service is fast. My faves are the spicy pork and veggies, the spicy beef, and the chop chae noodles, ooooh oooooh, and the fried mushrooms stuffed with steak, those are super yummy!
author: Kelly L.

description: This place is yummy and cheap - just how I like my Asian food (except sushi - cheap sushi is BAD). It's quickly becoming one of my favorite places because it's closeby, and my favorite items, udon bowl and kimchee, are fantastic. Had a bite of the bbq beef and wasn't impressed but overall, the food here is very good.
author: Sadia J.

description: Not quite Korean food; service was great, but the price isn't justified by the hole in the wall decor and the sauce heavy dishes. Nice place to people watch, but honestly, just go to a Korean market on Geary and make your own Korean food... it'll taste better and won't cost you 10-20 bucks a dish.
author: Andy A.

description: I would say Han's Hibachi is a solid joint but keep in mind that its just a typical fast-food korean joint.  I personally like going to Arang more but if you are in the mood for well priced huge meat dishes, I would say Han's is your better bet.  Came here for a late lunch and thought everything was decent.  Well priced and great proportions.  Dont come here if you are looking for a real korean dining experience.
author: Charles C.

description:
I went because I liked the one at Oakland, Jack London Square. I thought it'd be the same, menu and taste -- I was wrong on two fronts:
1. The menu here was a bit different...i actually got excited when i saw that they had tofu soup -- and I LOVE me some tofu soup, so i ordered it -- so that was the positive. 
2. The Negative -- NOT tasty -- they messed up the tofu soup! HOW HARD is it to mess this up?!?! It didn't even come with the egg for you to crack in AND they didn't EVEN offer you the egg until my bf asked them for one -- then they said..oh, it might not cook all the way....wth! Also, I didn't really like the chopped vegetable they had in the soup..it made it so that it had this weird crunchy texture to it...not a fan :(

Anyway, i probably acted like a baby about it and i probably won't go to this particular Hahn's again. However, I did feel bad afterwards, so to end this review on an O-Kay note -- the waiter was very nice, attentive and patient.
author: Julie M.

description: this is a great place for lunch. If I cant think of anything to eat around work, I usually go for Han's. The food has been the same since Ive had it here for the last 8 years. BBQ chicken is so good!
author: Gordon L.

description: Hahn's bbq is fantastic!  I go about once every other week, when I crave lots of meat.  I really like the pile of chicken (enough for dinner for two), the be bim bop and the kimchee.  The prices are very reasonable and the waiter is nice.   If you want something delicious, fast and cheap...go to Hahns.
author: James B.

description: Recently I have been to two different Hahn's in the city and both had excellent food.  I never expected a Korean BBQ place to be so tasty!  I had the pork noodle bowl at the one on Castro and 24th and can still taste it dancing on my taste buds right now.  So good I want some right now!
author: Cali Party Bus S.

description: Decent, not great, Korean BBQ... but I have a tremendous amount of respect for any restaurant that has items such as "the Meat Mountain" and the "Pile O' Pork" on its menu.   That's enough to get me to go back.
author: Andrew E.

description: Decent Korean 'flavored' (?) BBQ worth the money.....if you dig the flavor and fatty ribs. A value at close to tennish per meal; the service is satisfying and the meals will surely leave you full. Worth trying at least once since BBQ joints have a tendancy to not be on the same page. The menu is in gibberish.
author: Eugene G.

description: Holy crap. I just got done eating some takeout BBQ pork I got from Hahn's. I am kind of in a food coma, so I am not even sure what to write. Really tasty. Plenty of food. Even the rice was good. I was like the rice was watered with milk instead of water. Or something. As I said, I am kind of in a food coma. Time to take a nap. I think I'll finish this beer first. Or during. Zzzzzz...
author: Stu M.

description: I am only giving my thoughts on the bbq chicken and beef. Both were very good. I prefer the bbq chicken. The sauce is super good! Ive been here a couple of times when I was younger growing up here in the city. I wouldnt consider it great korean food but if you want good bbq chicken and beef. this is the place to go.
author: Joseph G.

description: Oh the spicy BBQ that makes me come back for seconds... I mean this place cooks a mean bbq!  Just go for the menu and grab anything that has bbq next to it and you'll be happy.  The food is plentiful and the meat is great.  Its always semi packed and the hostess is always so sweet.  You can count on a fast good meal whenever you pass by this place!  Grab a cold beer to wash down the fire in your mouth while you're at it!
author: Harry H.

description: Decent for the lunch special. I remember when I used to come here probably 8 years ago. The selection was a lot more slim, but the food was a hellavalot better. Anyhow decent lunch place.
author: Steven C.

description: Very small place, but I really enjoyed their food.  This Hahn's Hibachi has a different menu than the one in Noe Valley, although very similar.  I prefer this one.  The beboppin (?spelling) dish was so good and served in a very hot stone bowl.  A raw egg is place on top and when you mix the dish, it cooks from the heat of the bowl.  Was reluctant at first, but came to enjoy the experience....at a great price too.  Their beef is really tender and juicy.
author: Adrian N.

description: I think the only dish I have ever eaten here is the tofu & veggies (mild).  It is just so dang delicious that I can't quit.  My fiance usually gets a salad, so I like to steal some of his salad dressing and put it on my rice.  I could drink that stuff out of a pitcher.  So good!  And the super tall, skinny guy who works here is really nice!
author: Squirrel L.

description: I can't say whether this is authentic Korean, but it is TASTY. And when you ask for "spicy," they don't mess around. Order a few light beers, sit out on the sidewalk, and watch the Polk Street hipsters amble by.
author: Sahra H.

description: Man I love BBQ.  Man o man I love Korean BBQ.  This place is really not that different from the one on Irving.  Check out that Meat Mountain if you're on that meat diet.
author: patrick o.

description: Casual, yummy, quick, cheap, comfort food.  We always get the Be Bim Bop and the Pork Bulgogi and of course Kimchee. The Polk location is pleasant with plenty of tables and very friendly service.
author: L C.

description: I used to eat at their restaurant on Steiner several years ago. When i found this restaurant, I was excited to eat their food again. It's not the same. There must be something wrong with their food. The food wasn't fresh and the meat may have been spoiled. After eating, I didn't make it to Ocean Beach area because I had to stop at the Toys R Us at Masonic because I got the runs. It was not a nice trip back home, trying to find a public restroom ever few blocks.
author: David T.

description: I have nothing bad to say about Han's. Great food for the right price. I'd never been to Han's until my friends suggested we try it for lunch one day. I'd only moved to SF a few weeks before, so I really didn't know anything about the city. After that first lunch, I think I ate there for lunch every day for the rest of the week. And on the weekend, I went to the one closer to my apartment. This location gets crowded quickly during lunch, so plan on getting it to go.
author: Michael R.

description: I've been a little weary of eating at Hahn's Habachi because it always came across as a fast-food chain Korean restaurant...and that's exactly what it is! Although it carries a wide assortment of Korean delicacies, the food is mediocre. It's hard to eat at a real Korean restaurant, especially the kind where you can cook the meat at your table and then come to Hahn's. Granted, if you need a quick and cheap meal and you happen to be on Polk, it's not a bad option. The dol sot bimbibop (in the stone pot) was generous in size. The spicy pork bulgogi was tender but a bit greasy. Oh and this place doesn't serve those tiny little dishes you get at other Korean restaurants so you'll have to ask for some kimchi on the side.
author: Josephine H.

description: Reasonably priced and pretty decent overall. It's nothing amazing and not like the other Korean bbq joints where you can cook the food over your own charcoal. However, for such a small place they do their best to give you some fresh, hot food on some ridiculously large plates. To top it off, you get an interesting piece of Korean melon gum with your check, and its not half bad...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I'm not Korean, which is probably why I love this place. The portions are great. The short ribs are very tasty as well as the beef ribs and bbq chicken. I had the bbq eel recently  and it was really good. However, tell them to go easy on the sauce since it easily overpowers the sweet taste of the eel. My girlfriend is in love with the udon here. The folks that work here are always nice and professional. I do have some gripes though. No complimentary kimchee, which is just plain annoying. Also, water is served in paper cups, which seems wasteful to me. They've expanded the restaurant so there's alot more space now with a properly accessible bathroom. Authentic Korean cuisine or not, this place is a good place to get some delicious food.
author: Raymond P.

description: if you have a hankering for meat that doesn't break the bank, it's hard to beat this place. I have a soft spot for the sprout salad that is usually a side dish too. The soft tofu soups are excellent too!
author: Jan Michael K.

description: Oh Hahn's I really did want to like you! I went to the location in Noe Valley. Both of my visits were when I really needed some Asian-ish comfort food. First visit was for dinner -- I got the eel bowl to go. There was waaay too much teriyaki, glaze-type sauce ( it was NOT unagi sauce).  So on the second visit I thought that maybe I had aimed too high -- I should just stick with the meat. The same teriyaki, glaze type sauce smothered my meat. The meat wasn't too tough. I plan on rinsing off the sauce and using leftover meat in my udon.  Maybe if you ask for the sauce on the side?
author: Lisa M.

description: Great Korean Food!  Their BBQ Pork was out of this world, and their portion sizes were generous for the money.
author: Tony R.

description: let me make this clear - they make americanized (or gringo) version of korean food/bbq. It's like going to Chevy's for Mexican, you know what I mean.   Food is okay, and it's cheap.
author: ji k.

description: I hate eating IN this restaurant, so I highly recommend you do take-out.  It's so small and compact, and the server isn't the friendliest.  But if you want a good and filling semi-Korean meal, I recommend it.  It tastes pretty good, and it'll fill you up.
author: Jonathan B.

description: I go to school a block away, and this is my hmm-I-don't-know-what-to-eat place, because I'm always happy after some BBQ meat. The place is tiny so during lunch you're in for a little wait. Otherwise, service is good, food is good.
author: Ben L.

description:
love this spot. my rating consists of the following 
how many pieces of "meat" i have to leave aside by the end of my meal. =0   

which means this place rules, meat not mystery, spicy korean chicken is OH so good.
author: David R.

description:
Probably the least Korean Korean restaurant I've ever been to.  Forks instead of chopsticks, though admittedly this benefits me immensely.  The menu contains only English words, and there is no panchan (the numerous small plates)!

I ordered kalbi (or, as the menu descriptively called it, "BBQ Short Ribs") for 11.95$.  It tasted um a little like bulgogi?  I wasn't quite sure, but it didn't quite have the "kalbi" taste.  The plate was HUGE, 3 enormous strips of kalbi, rice, marinated bean sprouts, and I replaced the salad with kimchi.  Seriously, who eats salad at a Korean restaurant?

It's not the best Korean food I've ever had, but it's the only Korean place even reasonably close by, so I will probably be coming here a ton.  They do take out, accept credit cards, and my roommate likes their lunch specials.
author: emilie k.

description: i've always loved the barbecue sandwiches. bit expensive for a mere sandwich, but when you're a little tipsy and got a case for the munchees anything will do. wait that's not helping this restaurants review. Took a friend there for dinner and i got to say the food and service were great. The only reason i can hold off on a  5 star review is that every so often they change the menu up a bit. They made a big mistake taking away my favorite app and that's the now infamous Kim Chee Rolls. Bring it back and i'll Beyonce' the review up from a 4. But i doubt it. Nice Try though
author: graham c.

description: I have not had a bad meal or experience yet. I wandered in here for the first time about a year ago. I started with takeout and eventually got to eating lunch there too. I just had some more take out tonight and had a yummy meal. I got the Ribs Combo and Stuffed Mushroom appetizer and my friend had the Chicken BBQ sandwich. Both were delicious and large portions. The ribs were a bit of work, but worth the effort. The house salad that comes with it is simple, but tasty. Four stars because while it is very good, I've had better in the city. For the convenience, service, portions, and flavor I'll keep coming back.
author: S A.

description: i have been to Hahn's four times now, and not surprisingly I have gotten the samething everytime.  Their Sizzling Beef Bee-Bim-Bop is amazing, and single handedly has made me a huge fan of Korean-fare.  The seating in this Polk street spot is a little suspect if you come on a weekend afternoon, but ever so often, the B-B-B is worth the trip to Russian Hill...
author: Korey A.

description: Meh. The beef bi bim bop wasn't bad although i think i burnt myself about a million times on the bowl it was served in.  This place kinda skeeved me out.  I don't think I'll be back.  Next time I'll stay closer to home and go to a real Korean BBQ place.
author: cristina t.

description:
pros...haven't been here in over a decade, but i can still remember the first time when my friend said we were going to a "thai" place.  and then we end up here?  he was new to s.f., couldn't quite tell the difference between korean and thai, but what the heck!  but after the little faux pas, and terrible reprimanding he got, we ordered.

and was the best bulgogi i have had.  it was soo good, tasty, hot and soft.  the rice was sparkling and steamy.  even the desserts were cool and unusual, watermelon gum and watermelon Popsicle, too!?  how korean. just perfect on that cold august night in the city.  i can remember that night cause it was freaking cold, and we had just come back from wine country where it was hot and humid.  you could tell all the so-cal people like myself, cause we were still in shorts and t-shirts.  while all the s.f. locals had jeans and jackets.  

cons...well a heck of a long way to travel from my home in san diego.   parking, parking, parking, anywhere in this city is a great pain.
author: Joel G.

description: I had always wanted to check out this chain (even though I am not crazy about restaurant chains) so when I stumbled upon this location I didn't think twice. Walking in the place we found it was nearly empty and by the time we left it was packed...I really loved the Chicken Bibambap although it was my first. Awesome Chicken Lettuce Wrap Appetizer. Not too crazy about the pork here. I was a bit surprised at the Squid & Vegetable Tempura, the tempura was actually sweet, thus making the squid taste very much like a seafood donut. Not a bad thing, just more like dessert in an anago/ unagi sushi kind of way. Also, the portions are huge. Great for lunch.
author: Sloane M.

description: My favorite dining establishment.  Highly addictive BBQ chicken and BBQ chicken salad.  Good food, priced right.
author: Brent H.

description: While vacationing recently in San Francisco, my cousin, son and I got take-out at Hahn's.  I was pleased with the service.  They were quick and friendly.  I sat at a table outside while waiting for my food.  I ordered the of beef bbq and side order of the chop chae noodles.  By the time I got back to my hotel, the food was hot and stayed hot.  The portion was large.  The beef was tender and noodles were cooked just perfecty.   I will definitely return on my next trip.
author: Jen R.

description: foood is soooo yummy!!! love the spicy bbq pork. gotta go back for some more!
author: David W.

description: HH is the first Korean restaurant I've eaten at in SF and I fell in love with it instantly.  That was about 15 years ago and up until now, even living 50 miles away, I still frequent this joint.  I don't know, it must be the sauce. Use to take dates there when I was young and get brownie points J/k.  The food is delicious and savory.  Price is very reasonable. Damn, I want some now.  The only issue is parking, hard to find, but you can always double park and order to go. Yeee
author: Jay G.

description: Love this place for good portions of BBQ type meats over rice.  Also have some pretty good soups.
